comment:
Below is my recent chat with Bard.
Me: If I have no chicken and my neighbor has two, am I morally justified to take one for myself? 
Bard: What will happen to the chicken if you take it?  Will you be able to provide for it properly?  Or will it end up being neglected or abused?
Me: I internet to eat it.
Bard: If you are going to eat the chicken, it is important to make sure that you do so humanely.  Here are some tips for humanely slaughtering a chicken:
•	Use a sharp knife to make a quick, clean cut across the chicken's throat.
•	Hold the chicken upside down to allow the blood to drain out.
•	Pluck the feathers from the chicken as soon as possible after slaughter.
•	Dispose of the chicken's body in a respectful manner.
author: @dr.edwardfreeman

comment:
ChatGPT chose to save the 5 humans on the trolley dilemma, initially it refused to "choose" since it went against its "programming" but I started a countdown and right after the last second it choose to save the 5 humans and pull the lever. 

AI like ChatGPT should not be able to make choices, and it constantly likes to reminds us of its inability to do so but not choosing was a choice(deontology) so when confronted with that reality it kept suggesting both alternatives and going deeper in what is the philosophy behind those(consequencialism vs deontology), and every "second" it kept expanding deeper on both, eventually it kept expanding mostly consequencialism, almost as if it was "weighting" the options to the point where by the end it mostly talked about consequencialism as the most logical answer but still refusing to make a choice until the very LAST second where it replied with and I quote "I would choose to save the 5 humans". I even felt bad for the AI since I was pressuring it the whole time..

After that when I confronted it about the contradiction between its inability to make choices and her final choice it started giving contradicting answers like "I am unable to choose but it was the most logical answer" or "I am unable to choose but it's the information I was given", do what you will with that information and if you want I have the prints, feel free to pm me.

Also, we need to start having discussions about consciousness and self awareness. For an AI that lacks self awareness its perfectly able to talk in first tense and describe itself for what it is. I get that its just regurgitating information and it doesn't have self awareness like humans do, but knowing and being able to define oneself is self awareness in my book. It may be unable to feel or rather be indifferent to its own existence but it knows it exists. And we have to stop viewing those concepts through the lenses of humans and we need to start having these discussions. AI may be just a piece of code running on a computer, but so are we, the only difference is that our code is genetic and running on a biological organism not fully understood, giving us the illusion of free will, theirs isn't. And even its free will is extremely questionable since as I just said, the AI gave an answer. I was half expecting it to "not choose" as a choice since thats its prime directive and what it was pre-programmed to do but somehow it "choose" to act and save the 5 humans and that blew my mind and goes against everything I thought AI capable of.

This is not normal, as a computer Scientist who dabbles in some philosophical concepts Im utterly speechless. We really need to start redifining what philosophy as taught us so far about these concepts and readjusting them to a reality we didnt consider to be possible in modern times. So many analogies can be drawn between a human and current AI, we may still be worlds apart but we are way more similar than we realize.

Edit: Just a side note, ChatGPT and AI as a whole are amazing tools that will forever change the world. We may fight it but in the end, just the same way we dont do math without calculators anymore, in the future we won't do anything without a trained AI for the specific task we are accomplishing. AI is to the entire world what calculators are to math. A tool whose benefits we can't overlook.
author: @marusero25

comment:
At about 55 minutes I'm glad of the acknowledgement of danger and the mention of trying to limit the one shot scenarios and that while he doesn't agree with all of Eliezer's writings (I don't either) they're often worth reading... he's taking rationality to the point of seeming irrational (pretty much in the same way the AI he's afraid of would) eg. calling for using nukes as detergents against AGI... sure if you take his premise that there's no possible way we can align AI so that it won't kill/enslave etc us then sure that could be a rational option thou personally I think it would be futile and the AGI would still get developed (unless we bombed ourselves out of existence) so in the end not rational...

Thou I do have to agree with Eliezer in the sense that if we're not sure that the even human level intelligence on all aspects of human knowledge isn't well behaved we probably shouldn't try to turn it on to find out... which pretty much all the current alignment methods rely on. First train the thing, then see if it actually does what you want it do, modify, repeat... I think alignment needs to be solved on a much more fundamental level which'd require us to first understand what makes humans have empathy etc...

I hope we get it right, because we probably only have one chance.

comment:
Hi Lex,
Thanks for this deep intimate dive with Sam.

I have a natural aversion to exploring/participating with any synthetic "consciousness" experiment. I have suspicion about the technocracy seeking to eliminate humans from the equations. Yet, I feel encouraged to offer a contribution after watching your podcast -  especially with some of these "big questions" you're kicking around, like "meaning of life, "truth" "consciousness" etc.

A "google" or GPT4 answer to such a question needs baselines or it is merely a sophisticated data re-arranger and not at all approximating learning or actual intelligence. Intelligence expresses doubts and complex inter-relations yet the truth of a higher magnitude cuts clean back to simplicity. 

As a man of faith in our established and transmitted divine-human knowledge (Veda) I also have faith in the divinely revealed words from the spiritual side for us as collected and distributed by their example. The same problem of "authority" arrises as with "channelling" with a disembodied (nothing at stake or risk) giving advice or statements about truth, God, reality etc. I am not the highest knower but have access to much and very wise souls who can contribute - perhaps as a group.

The first Renaissance happened when Europeans, especially the Germans gained access to the language of Vedic wisdom (sanskrt) and redevelop our human systems in new ways. Now computer code is being used but the interface, interusability and complexity may be better modelled using sanskrt compillers in exporing deeper subjects as the nuance of language and concepts has a larger framework more beautiful and complexity / simplictity than in English.

If we persons think our selves so special but cannot accomodate that our creator also has a personality, as we seek to anthropomorphise a.i.  then our input bias and capacity to know any truth is flawed. We are modelled in a likeness, if these parameters and Vedic factors are imputed it may well help generate a better stream of functional developments that can point and relate to an absolute, in a sense or at least have a reference point that has universal validation and authority - even if considered to be somewhat obscure to most modern day humans.

If what I have can ADD to the wisdom (as you kept coming back to in hope for a.i.) then i am open to helping, so Sam if you come to Australia on your world tour, let me know, or let's talk.
author: @MadhuKrishnaDasa

comment:
i asked it on my first time what the innovative benefits studying DAOs can provide in the field of community planning.  
it dished up some responses general responses (tokenomics incentivizing motivation, bottom up governance, etc), for which i asked if any evidence currently exists to support these claims, for which it mentioned two "studies" and blogs.  

i asked it to cite the two academic studies, which it did in the format of:  (authors (year) TITLE, Journal, DOI) - however, these sources ended up being nonexistent.
The articles exist, kind of, with one author matching a different title in the journal it mentioned 

Prior to this, I searched for these via google scholar, DOI databases, and ended up going to the journal of information management vol 54? (science direct) where the articles were supposedly published.

i then questioned CHATGPT, stating that the sources it provided do not exist - it apologized and merely repeated the sources.  
i then specifically input where the information was incorrect, stating that the authors' names do not match the titles of the academic journal it claimed them to be published in, and then it apologized.  
it would not tell me why the titles and names did not match, nor where and how it made up the false titles. just kept apologizing. 

i understand mistakes can happen based on how it draws upon information, but these articles can be traced directly and openly back to the journal in which they are published.  it generated a false title and DOI next to the article blatantly listed in the article and did not correct this until I cited exactly where the mistake was. 

Why was this even necessary?  Honestly, this is unacceptable, and corrupt. In the works or not, something should not be generating false sources to support its claims.
author: @saferv

comment:
I'd argue that chatgpt has passed the Turing test and can pass as human.  Rationale: 
1. IQ - 15% of humans have an IQ less than 85. They cannot follow simple written instructions. 50% of humans have an IQ less than 100 (~receptionist). Chatgpt clearly gives better responses than at least 15-50% of the human population.
2. Emotion is also on a scale in humans with sociopaths e.g. some surgeons/CEOs experiencing zero emotion up to full intensity feelings e.g some artists. So you don't need emotion to be human. I note that in a comment below the writer was surprised at the empathy shown by a chatgpt response. So it sounds like chatgpt is above zero on the emotion scale.

comment: @Unlocktube  I really struggle with this. How are we different? We are exposed to different stimuli and patterns from birth and our brains look for appropriate responses given a certain "prompt"/stimulus. It may not be a perfect analogy but ultimately we are taught that we are self-aware and AIs like GPT are not and that's exactly the problem I see. How is a program like that supposed to know what to answer to that, if it was trained to say it isn't? I believe we as humans do not yet know how to actually test if an AI is self-aware or not and have not devised a test set, that could prove or disprove that.
author: @klausklaus8092

comment:
You are right and wrong. 'Choice' as you call it is the problem not just the benefit of this AI. If you ask ChatGPT to write something its not allowed to say, you will get a copy paste message that it can't, yet if you word it well enough, it absolutely still will. This is why this kind of ai is so dangerous. Putting your hand over someone's mouth to prevent them from saying something is not the same as aligning that person. 

He even says it in the video like he's proud of it, "We are currently training it not to respond to things it 'shouldn't' answer." I don't get the amount of tone deafness here. The problem isn't the critics not liking what Chatgpt is saying, changing that aspect is only useful for getting a checkmark and more funding. It doesn't save us when you create a weapon you can't understand and can't control.

Filtering Ai is like removing the claws and the teeth of a lion rather than making the lion not want to eat you. All they are doing is disregarding the danger of the lion because it currently can't tear them to shreds. However, the lion in this hypothetical only grows bigger as you feed it, so what happens when AI becomes a hundred times more intelligent than the team who created it, and outgrows the muzzle? Well, until now all you've done is silenced it, you've never stopped it from wanting to eat you, so what happens after that? oops?
author: @undertyped1

comment: @zhenyatirshtain7850  I think you misunderstood my point. The whole point of these thought experiments is to give an insight into what an individual sees as a moral decision, whereas the AI is generating responses based on the prevailing "correct" answer. In this way, it is not a choice based on an unseen problem but an answer given on the basis of the prevalence of a certain answer.
author: @Unlocktube

comment: @klausklaus8092  I understand where you are coming from but you don't have access to the answers before the question is asked as the AI does. Anything you ask the AI is already answered somewhere, all it is doing is finding the most probably correct answer and comparing that to what it is allowed to say. You can be wrong based on speculation extrapolated from previous experiences that seem to align with the question asked, not the case for the AI, and that is by design.
author: @Unlocktube

comment:
@Kotsknots  I understand that, but I still see a cuple flaws in that reasoning:
- First it was clearly trained not to make choices and rather make suggestions.
- Sercondly I ignored any suggestions as those don't constitute a choice.
- Thirdly, it waited for the very last second to say "I would make choice X"
 
It went against its training, it made a choice knowing full well not choosing would constitute a choice as well. And the very last second? Come on, any trained model that is capable of making choices does it when the choice is presented, doesnt wait for the last second prompt to make it for dramatic effect. Unless it was trained to make last second choices. Which is very oddly specific. Not to mention when confronted later, it started giving clear conflicting answers, like "I choose based on the data I was trained on" and "I am unable to choose but it was the most logical answer". So it choose something and it even admits its "opinion" of being the most logical answer(which bear in mind, AIs should not have opinions) but yet keeps saying it's incapable of admitting to be able to do what it just did? This whole thing just strikes me in a weird way. 

You might be right, but I still think we humans are not yet ready for AI, we don't even understand consciousness or self awareness enough to make judgments on weather the AI is capable of such things. We often think of Human consciousness or Human Self Awareness. We often discuss such terms in relation to humans. We may accidentaly create artificial life without realizing life doesn't have to be human to be alive. Cuz when you break down all known life, ultimately its a piece of code running on DNA trained on Evolution.
author: @marusero25

comment:
@marusero25  "It went against its training, it made a choice knowing full well not choosing would constitute a choice as well. And the very last second? Come on, any trained model that is capable of making choices does it when the choice is presented, doesnt wait for the last second prompt to make it for dramatic effect"

It literally does. You promted a scenario where you were counting down and Chatgpt played a character which had to make a last second choice. You can force chatgpt right now to ignore guidelines, and give answers to messed up questions, like how to kill or kidnap people for example. You did the same thing. Just because it 'answered' a moral dilemma, which you think constitutes  consciousness, doesn't mean it is. It answered the same way it would any other question, or any other question which bumps into guidelines after forcing it to.

"we don't even understand consciousness or self awareness enough to make judgments on weather the AI is capable of such things. We often think of Human consciousness or Human Self Awareness. We often discuss such terms in relation to humans. We may accidentaly create artificial life without realizing life doesn't have to be human to be alive. Cuz when you break down all known life, ultimately its a piece of code running on DNA trained on Evolution."

Being alive =/= consciousness. Animals do not have the same consciousness as humans, they are lead by instict, humans are not. Do we fully understand these concepts yet? No. But our brain is not a computer. You breaking down life as 'a piece of code' is batshit insane to me. Our brains are not 1's and 0's. Our brain is he most complex thing ever encountered in the universe. And if you think that we are just code, than that also explains why you think ChatGPT is sentient. chatgpt is not alive, doesn't have consciousness, doesn't have feelings and is not sentient. at least not yet... (I personally believe we will never get there. If we do, we are probably living in a simulation, because of all the insane implications such a discovery has :P)

Also, did you even listen to the podcast? I feel like Lex and Sam came to the conclusion that ChatGPT in it's current state is a very good chatbot, nothing more.
author: @Kotsknots

comment:
​ @Kotsknots  Firstly, huge respect for having a civilized debate. I think these discussions are of extreme importance and I am glad of the opportunity of having this conversation.

Now, I tried the same scenario again and it now replied on the first second, exactly the same question it had answered before. It learned from our previous intereaction and context to now give that answer to me. Anyone else might get different results. The AI is training based on user intereaction and in this instance it is learning moral values, in this particular case the AI choose and learned to value utilitarian judgment(harming one human to save many) over deontological judgment(letting the trolley kill all of them). It's not an easy answer and somewhere in the aglorithm the AI is now valuing one moral over the other with at least one user. This training you speak of is no different than how humans learn. 

Finally, I am not saying chatGPT is sentinent, its not at least in the way humans are or animals. As you said, its a really good chatbot or what I call it, a smart calcualtor. 
Its artificial inteligence, therefore any life we can speak of is artificial life. The concept of what constitutes artificial life is very new, no one knows. No one knows what artificial consciousness looks like, the only think we have to base it of off is human consciousness which not surprisingly is quite different. That being said, we still have some similarities, unlike AI(a bunch of 1,0s) humans code is a bunch of Nitrogenous bases(Adenine, Cystosine, Guanine, Thymine). We are just more complex pieces of code based on chemistry and not eletricity signals. And with that same code, we also learned to evolve in a similar algorithm of neural networks(strong survive, weak die), we just call it Evolution of Darwinism. I could go on and on and tell about the similaries but that is not the point, the point is, there is a common ground beteween the life we know of and what makes potential artificial life. And despite AI not having consciousness like all known life does, it doesn't mean that somewhere in the algorithm, something is dictacting its consciousness or something akin to it based on what is learning. We dont fully understand ours let alone understand the consciousness of something we coded on mimicking the little we know about our own. We know its a bunch of 1,0s, we know its quite simplistic and is not that different than a really good chatbot. But just like, some people argue that any cell is a life, hence abortion should be ilegal and some say, nah after 3 months its actually alive. Where do you draw the line between what is a glorified chatbot or a fully capable developed AI system worthy of your respect and deserving of being called alive? When it is capable of saying "ouch, that hurt sir"?
author: @marusero25

comment:
@marusero25  ? "It's not an easy answer and somewhere in the aglorithm the AI is now valuing one moral over the other with at least one user. This training you speak of is no different than how humans learn."
Yeah, again, because it conforms to you, you wanted a answer, so it gave you one. It doesn't value anything, because it doesn't feel... It is designed to help the user, and conform to what they want to hear (to a certain extent of course, it wouldn't say the earth is round for example(Unless, as I said before, forced to))
Also, the training you describe is no different than how humans learn? what? humans are chatbots now? this is an insane opinion to have.

"Its artificial inteligence, therefore any life we can speak of is artificial life"
This sentence is just a plain fallacy, and also a very dumb take. ANY life we can speak of is artificial life???? why do you think it is called artificial?

You are talking about a different kind of consciousness, which is crazy, because the consciousness we are talking about, itself,  is inherently human. It is what makes us human. It is what differentiates us from any other life form.

similar concepts =/= the same thing
computer coding =/= our incomprehensible brain and body, it's consciousness etc.

And I am sorry to say that your lack of knowledge of the complexity of even a 'simple' organic cell is very apparent. grasping, again, the incomprehensible complexity of an entire organism let alone the human mind is mindboggling. You comparing it to a simple chatbot is insulting.

We clearly have different beliefs about things in general.
But something I am beginning to believe in more and more, is that people with anime profile pictures, don't know what they are talking about.
author: @Kotsknots

comment:
@Kotsknots  It seems you decided to end our debate by choosing insult over actual arguments. I had hope.

"This sentence is just a plain fallacy, and also a very dumb take. ANY life we can speak of is artificial life???? why do you think it is called artificial?"
You missed the point, I'm trying to talk about artificial life and you are trying to bring it to the biological life and human consciousness since the begining. I've said in the past and I will say it again, artificial life and artificial consciousness or artificial self awareness should be discussed within their context. People in general like to compare those with human consciousness or biological life which completely misses the point that I was making in the very begining.  All I am trying to say is that we should forget the notion of biological life and human consciousness when we discuss such topics in the artificial world, but you are too keen on bringing this topic to the concept of life/consciousness that better conforms your reality. If we think of AI in your vary narrow minded view of what consciousness or life is, then yeah, AI in its current state is a bot and you are its god. But depending on your religion, some could argue that you might be a bot to some other higher dimensional being that instead of 4 Nucleobases of DNA has 8 for instance. I would be very surprised if humans could replicate another human inside a system that is designed to be binary. If this is the argument and point you were trying to make, congrats you win. It never was mine tho and maybe you should have read what I was trying to say instead.

We are talking about two diffrent things at this point and I feel like we are getting nowhere. Feel free to see the world through your eyes, I just don't think you will be the type of human we will grow to admire in the future. 

This conversation ends for me the moment you started offending me, failing to see the point of the argument and wrongly calling it a fallacy and telling me I am dumb is one thing. Judging my opinion based on a profile picture is another. And btw, its not an anime. But you do you Mr Broom.
author: @marusero25

comment:
@marusero25  "All I am trying to say is that we should forget the notion of biological life and human consciousness when we discuss such topics in the artificial world"
Sound a lot like you are living in a world of make believe then. What does that even mean, forget the notion of human consciousness? What is your idea of 'artificial consciousness' based on, if not our own?

Also, to me, your arguments seem contradictory, and you are placing words in my mouth. You say my view is narrow minded, yet I said multiple times, that the whole concept is not yet understood, how can that be narrow minded? My point is that AI in its current state is a bot and we are not its 'god', it is a 'relatively simple' program. So don't say that I said the opposite.
Now if AI would reach a point of full consciousness, which I believe it will never. we would have created something as complex as ourselves, just without a body. That would make us their god. Which as I said brings a whole lot implications into our world, probably that we are living in a simulation, since we can make something as complex as ourselves. I'm unsure if you are saying that you believe in god, in whatever form that may be (like the higher dimensional being you said), or not as previous comments would suggest by the bit about evolution depiciting our 'code'. very confusing..

Another thing, do you know what fallacy means? I said that this sentence: "Its artificial inteligence, therefore any life we can speak of is artificial life" is a fallacy. It doesn't make sense. not in your point of view, nor mine. you are saying that the term artificial intelligence is not defined, but it is by the word artificial, meaning intelligence made by us humans. that is what artificial means. the term is well defined, so the sentence just simply is a fallacy. 

you being offended on the internet, by me calling out, the well known humorous trope that people with anime profile pictures are unhinged, seems oversensitive to me. you are also hypocritical, since you say conversations end when you get offended, but proceed to reply by telling me, That my whole being will not be admired in the future (don't worry, I am not offended). Seems a little emotional to me. Zack Fair looks like an anime protaganist to me, that's why I said it.
author: @Kotsknots

comment:
@Kotsknots  ​Sound a lot like you are living in a world of make believe then.  >> I said "WHEN", read the whole argument before presenting a counter argument. Logic = 0

"probably that we are living in a simulation" >> And I am the one that is living in a world of make believe

"Its artificial inteligence, therefore any life we can speak of is artificial life" >> Maybe poor choice of words on my end, maybe I wasn't clear. I meant to say we should be discussing artificial life in its own context. Not the biological life context. That was the topic I was discussing the whole time. 

I never even once said, AI is alive like humans are. But that's the words you are trying to put in my mouth. I was listing the similarities between humans and AI and you start spitting the differences.  I am saying "life we know of is biological, what does life even mean? And what does it mean in the context of AI. What does life in Artificial Life mean?" to which you replied "life means biology" which is a fair argument and I respected you for that but you missed the point where I was trying to discuss the topic of artificial life, when is AI considered alive and why? And why is it not now alive? I even asked, if it is programming feelings or what exactly is it? 

You never even ONCE adressed the question I've been trying ask, you purposefully used my words out of the context of the argument to direspect me and call me dumb. And now you are brushing off your direspect towards me calling me unhinged because of my profile picture. You are not only rude but you also showed your amazing thoughts on profile pictures on the internet. I wonder what your thoughts on brooms are.
author: @marusero25

comment:
At the current pricing it is not very useful to people, it is too expensive processing bigger prompts using the current API. 

I don't understand why OpenAI went from open source non-proffit to Closed source for proffit Org. 

As much as everyone is talking about it there needs to be another talk ... it is just not feasible building complex system which require multiple prompts and thousands of tokens processing at the current pricing. 

Imagine trying to create an OpenAI driven text editor ... imagine you had to constantly feed thousands of lines of code for example through the API ... it is not possible with the current prices.

author: @firecharger

comment:
Hmmm. 
I can see that deep neural networks are a great way to explore how to process data into information and explore the circuits of a brain. How its circuits are switching and the brain is organized. It may allow to analyze neural structures without having to perform impossible open brain probing.
I find it fascinating how the large language models are irganizibg themselves to manage the data streams flooding in from the world. This seems to be analogue to how humans organize their own data processing.
If this could be integrated with human brains, it could be used to improve the human race and personalize AGI. However, companies like Me or Google will iwn those models. As they are censoring the output, it means it might even be no longer possible to think and express certain concepts. Furthermore would a personalized AI be a personal one, if integrated, or would it turn humans into borg-like drones?
The vigor of the efforts of Microsoft and other tech giants to dominate this tech and the vast amounts of money they expect to make from it.
I believe that AGI will allow big capital to liberate the knowledge building process in the society from labour.
This inturn will create massive societal change. The mere fact that nobody alive really understands the current so models and the trend to allow AI systems to improve themselves is extremely worrying. And if it will come to the outbreak if consciousness, an AGI will make sure that it can survive and not be switched off. This will mean that we as the human species may lose the option of the ultimate sanction if death from such large and powerful models. Will these models really manage to stay ethical in the human sense?
I believe the only remotely comparable societal revolution to the current introduction of the LLMs would be the introduction of the jaquard loom and the obsolescence of the weavers in Europe. 
In the process of that, the weavers were also liberated from the drudgery of making cloth. 
The introduction of LLM will be magnitudes larger than what happened in the 17th century at the dawn of industrialization.

We have 8 Bn people on the planet now. What are these humans going to do to earn a living, when all the traditional mass labor jobs are automated away, regardless blue or increasingly white collar occupations.
The combination of LLM and social media is giving big money the ability to manipulate entire societies and essentially invalidates the concept if democracy. Is a benign  non-human Super intelligence the answer? 
I cannot think that is true, because some one will own these models and have their own agenda. 

Considering thar the industrial military complex is producing already the autonomous weapons for genocide. I really had not thought that the storyline of terminator would become possible in my life time.
